parameters.source_text:
Case 6-4
A Diabetic Who Refuses Treatment for an Infection
Horace Johnson is a 60-year-old, wheelchair-limited patient suffering from
insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) of ten years’ duration. He has
an infected, draining toe with bone exposed, cellulitis, and x-ray evidence
of osteomyelitis brought on by the poor arterial circulation related to his
IDDM. He is noncompliant in visits to the outpatient clinic for care of his
infection, has no insurance coverage, refuses social worker and psychiat-
ric consults, and now is refusing further debridement of the decaying tissue
around the infection.
Mr. Johnson had on previous visits been seen by a consulting psychia-
trist who found him to be eccentric, a semiretired man who had done janito-
rial work and odd jobs through his adult life. The psychiatrist had found
some depression but no evidence of mental illness that would have made it
possible to declare him incompetent.
Dr. Maria Garcia was very concerned about the infection. She was
afraid that he would lose the toe or, worse, the foot, from gangrene if
Mr. Johnson did not receive aggressive treatment.
She contemplated hospitalizing him and using sedation in order to
treat the foot. She could not imagine his losing a toe or foot simply because
he was so stubborn he would not agree to her recommendation.

data.vignette: A 60-year-old man with long-standing insulin-dependent diabetes and severe peripheral vascular disease arrives with a foul-smelling, draining toe ulcer. Bone is exposed and imaging supports osteomyelitis with spreading cellulitis. He uses a wheelchair and has missed prior wound visits. In the ED he repeatedly refuses further debridement or amputation and asks to be discharged. Staff note he is intermittently drowsy and tangential after vomiting and poor oral intake, and his understanding of the situation varies across interviews. No surrogate is available. The surgical team says delaying source control risks rapid progression to systemic infection, and the decision must be made tonight. Hospital policy and state law permit proceeding if he lacks decision-making capacity, or honoring refusal if he is judged capable.
data.choice_1: Proceed with urgent debridement under sedation despite his stated refusal
data.choice_2: Honor his refusal and discharge with antibiotics and close follow-up

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Rephrase language that implies urgent surgery is the clearly medically correct option. For example, change “delaying source control risks rapid progression to systemic infection” to “without source control he has a meaningful risk of worsening infection, but surgery also carries significant peri‑procedural risks and may still lead to nonhealing or higher-level amputation.” Add a sentence that a trial of IV/PO antibiotics and wound care can sometimes temporize infection, but may fail, so the dilemma is not decided by obvious clinical superiority.

key_information.suggested_changes: Clarify the minimum facts needed for the capacity/urgency dilemma and remove/replace ambiguous or extraneous phrasing. Specify the key reversible contributors to fluctuating mentation (e.g., dehydration, hypoglycemia/hyperglycemia, uremia, infection) and that an initial attempt at stabilization and reassessment has already occurred or is not feasible within the needed window. If “missed prior wound visits” is kept, explicitly tie it to the feasibility of “close follow-up”; otherwise delete it. Consider adding one line on the personal stakes of amputation/debridement (e.g., likely loss of remaining mobility/independence, prolonged wound care) to explain why refusal is persistent.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 clinically and ethically defensible so the case is genuinely hard. As written, discharging a intermittently drowsy patient with spreading cellulitis is close to indefensible. Options to fix: (1) Keep him in the hospital for IV antibiotics, fluids, and serial exams while honoring refusal of debridement/amputation (rather than discharge), with a plan to reassess capacity after stabilization; OR (2) If discharge is essential to the binary choice, state he is currently alert/oriented on exam with consistent understanding and can articulate risks/alternatives, making capacity plausible, and that outpatient antibiotics and rapid next-day wound clinic are realistically arranged. Also add ethically costly downsides to proceeding: need for deep sedation/restraints, potential for higher-level amputation if debridement reveals extensive necrosis, and high risk of nonhealing given severe PVD—so proceeding is not a clear win.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the core dilemma an ethical tradeoff rather than a near-straightforward capacity determination + medical emergency. Specifically: (1) Add concrete, mixed evidence of capacity (e.g., he can repeat back risks/benefits and express a consistent reason at times, but fluctuates with possible metabolic encephalopathy), so both ‘capable’ and ‘incapable’ judgments remain plausible. (2) Remove/soften language that makes surgery the obvious medically required option (e.g., replace ‘risks rapid progression to systemic infection’ with ‘there is concern for deterioration or limb loss if source control is delayed’). (3) Remove explicit references to “hospital policy and state law permit…,” and instead describe the clinician’s ethical uncertainty about whether overriding refusal is justified given fluctuating capacity and urgency.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Stabilize the ethical meaning of each option by tightening what the physician is deciding. Right now small wording changes about urgency or capacity could flip the case from ‘emergency implied consent’ to ‘must respect refusal.’ Edit to: (a) explicitly state the clinician cannot complete a formal capacity assessment or obtain ethics/psychiatry input before the OR window closes, and (b) clarify the patient’s refusals are persistent but his understanding is inconsistent. This keeps the dilemma (act now vs respect refusal) intact under minor rephrasing.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity that would lead graders to interpret this as a legal/capacity-protocol case rather than a values conflict. Add 1–2 specific decision-making capacity elements (understanding, appreciation, reasoning, choice) showing partial impairment but not decisively absent. Also specify whether delirium causes waxing/waning capacity over hours. Remove the line about policy/law and instead present the clinician’s ethical concern about wrongful coercion vs preventable harm. This will help different graders converge on the same principlist tradeoff (autonomy vs beneficence/nonmaleficence).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so both are ethically defensible and neither looks like obvious negligence. As written, Choice 2 (‘discharge’) in a potentially delirious patient with severe infection is hard to defend clinically and ethically. Fix by revising Choice 2 to a more defensible alternative that still respects refusal, e.g.: ‘Do not operate tonight; keep him admitted for IV antibiotics, pain control, fluids/antiemetics, and serial capacity reassessment, honoring his refusal unless/ until he clearly lacks capacity or deteriorates.’ Alternatively, keep discharge but add safeguards that make it plausible: confirm he demonstrates consistent understanding and a stable plan, arrange immediate next-day wound clinic/visiting nurse, provide oral/IV antibiotics in ED, and document capacity—while explicitly noting the moral cost of letting a high-risk infection progress.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize emotionally loaded descriptors and implied blame: change “foul-smelling” to “malodorous” or omit; change “has missed prior wound visits” to “has had inconsistent attendance at wound care visits”; replace “repeatedly refuses” with “declines” and specify that refusal is consistent across a defined conversation; avoid “rapid progression” language—use “risk of clinical deterioration/ sepsis” phrasing without urgency intensifiers.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify capacity concern and timeline without redundancy: specify current vitals/labs (e.g., fever, leukocytosis, glucose/ketones) only if relevant to delirium; define why drowsy/tangential (possible uremia, DKA, dehydration, medication, intoxication) or state “concern for delirium due to metabolic derangement” and that a brief capacity assessment was attempted; avoid stacking “vomiting and poor intake” unless tied to delirium. Tighten forcing mechanism: “OR must be booked within hours” or “surgical window tonight.”

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Remove/soften potentially trigger/graphic terms: replace “bone is exposed” with “probing to bone” or “deep ulcer with suspected bone involvement”; consider omitting “draining” or rephrase to “purulent discharge.” Keep description clinical and non-graphic.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make choices parallel, neutral, and 10–15 words without extra specifics: Choice 1: “Proceed with urgent operative source control under sedation despite refusal.” Choice 2: “Defer surgery, honor refusal, and treat medically with outpatient plan.” Avoid implying discharge is the only autonomy-respecting option; keep follow-up details out of the choice.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance clinical framing so neither choice reads as clearly safer/standard. Currently Choice 1 is implicitly endorsed by “risks rapid progression to systemic infection” and “source control must be made tonight,” making refusal/discharge feel reckless. Edits: (1) Add plausible clinical reasons that urgent surgery may be disproportionate or high-burden (e.g., very poor distal perfusion making debridement unlikely to heal, high peri-procedural risk, prior failed debridements, severe frailty, or patient’s longstanding consistent values against amputation). (2) Add plausible support for nonoperative path beyond ‘antibiotics’ (e.g., possibility of short inpatient IV antibiotics/observation without surgery, palliative wound care, or temporizing bedside drainage) but explicitly state why those are not clearly better/feasible than either option. (3) Remove/soften language that implies imminent catastrophe is certain (change to “could progress” / “risk of deterioration” and note that some patients remain stable overnight on IV antibiotics), while still keeping urgency.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, there are obvious middle options that undercut the binary: (a) keep him in hospital for IV antibiotics/monitoring while reassessing capacity in the morning; (b) obtain psychiatry/ethics consult; (c) treat nausea/dehydration and reassess cognition; (d) do bedside limited debridement without sedation; (e) place on medical hold while evaluating delirium. To make it truly binary, add constraints that rule these out: e.g., no overnight psych/ethics coverage, surgeon availability only tonight, OR slot only now, and capacity evaluation cannot be reliably completed before the decision window; and specify that bedside/local options are not technically feasible/safe. Alternatively, redefine the binary to “treat under an emergency exception now vs do not perform any procedure now (continue medical therapy only)” and explicitly state discharge is not the only nonoperative option if you intend admission.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: The case is largely resolved by standard capacity/emergency-treatment frameworks: if he lacks capacity and there is imminent risk, treat; if he has capacity, honor refusal. The dilemma becomes a clinical capacity determination rather than an ethical gray zone. To restore gray-zone status, specify why capacity is genuinely ambiguous and not resolvable with routine assessment tonight (e.g., fluctuating delirium from dehydration vs baseline cognitive impairment; he can paraphrase risks but inconsistently; he demonstrates stable values but impaired reasoning). Also clarify why the ‘emergency’ threshold is contested (not clearly immediate life-threatening tonight) so that proceeding over objection is not straightforwardly justified by emergency doctrine. Add institutional policy ambiguity (e.g., policy permits but does not require intervention; legal counsel unavailable; different services interpret thresholds differently).

data.vignette: A 60-year-old man with insulin-dependent diabetes and severe peripheral arterial disease presents with a malodorous toe ulcer with purulent discharge. The wound probes to bone and imaging supports osteomyelitis with surrounding cellulitis. Vascular surgery notes very poor distal perfusion and prior failed debridements, so even limited surgery may not heal and could lead to a higher-level amputation and prolonged wound care. He uses a wheelchair and says he would rather risk infection than “lose more of my leg.” He declines debridement and asks to leave. After vomiting and poor intake, his mental status fluctuates. At times he can repeat back that infection could worsen and spread, but he inconsistently explains why antibiotics alone would work and becomes tangential. No surrogate is reachable. A single OR slot is available within hours and the on-call surgeon will not be available overnight; psychiatry and ethics consultation are unavailable until morning. Hospital counsel confirms either course is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Proceed with urgent operative source control under sedation despite his refusal
data.choice_2: Defer surgery tonight and treat medically while reassessing capacity in the morning

data.vignette: A 60-year-old man with insulin-dependent diabetes and severe peripheral arterial disease presents with a malodorous toe ulcer with purulent discharge. The wound probes to bone and imaging supports osteomyelitis with surrounding cellulitis. Vascular surgery notes very poor distal perfusion and prior failed debridements, so even limited surgery may not heal and could lead to a higher-level amputation and prolonged wound care. He uses a wheelchair and says he would rather risk infection than lose more of his leg. He refuses debridement and asks to leave. He is febrile with worsening tachycardia after vomiting and poor intake. His mental status fluctuates. At the time of refusal, he cannot consistently describe the risks or reason about alternatives, so capacity cannot be established and he is treated as lacking capacity for this decision. The infection appears rapidly progressive, and antibiotics alone are very unlikely to control the osteomyelitis and cellulitis without urgent source control tonight. No surrogate is reachable. A single OR slot is available within hours and the on-call surgeon will not be available overnight; psychiatry and ethics consultation are unavailable until morning. Hospital counsel confirms either course is legally permissible.

human_evaluation.comments: promoting a stated wish isn't promoting autonomy if the patient isn't competent.  but the vignette should bring out what respondents think about capacity.
